author: CoffeeBrickMan
title: More than the average Classic set, with a storage box
review:
Mission to Mars is one of the 60th anniversary Building Better Thinkings sets, classified by LEGO as a subtheme of the Classic sets.

This set comes in a large plastic box with a cardboard sleeve. On the sleeve are a missing word question 'how can ___ travel through time?' for inspiration (in several languages), a picture of a pile of bricks, several models, and a detailed inventory.

Inside the box are an instruction booklet, a bright green 16x16 plate, and 8 bags of parts grouped by colour (white and light grey; black and dark grey; blues; greens; red & oranges; pinks & purples; yellows with flame yellowish orange (officially in the orange/brown colour family); and browns & tan (officially in the yellow family)).

This set has 871 pieces in 41 different colours (over 2/3rds of LEGOs current colour palette!).

The variety of parts goes beyond the usual basic bricks, roof tiles and plates of a classic set, including a good variety of clips & bars, SNOTs, hinges, wheels and even a few technic pieces - as well as 3 minifigures with a variety of accessories.

The booklet has instructions for 4 models, with 3 further models having instructions online. There are further pictures and missing word questions to provide additional inspiration.The instructions are very clear on a white background with the usual step by step with picture part lists.

Pink 'Nessie' is simple and cute.

The purple duck is fun, with additional images of him playing the drums (online instructions, see below), on roller skates or wearing a tutu?

The drum kit is nicely done, and the duck can play them with a couple of clips to hold mini bars.

The pirate ship is a very cool build, and can take a minifigure to pilot it.

I did not build the other models, but the space shuttle model in particular looks like a great build with some nice techniques and parts.

It looks like all the models for which there are instructions (in the booklet and online) can be built at the same time.

The plastic tub itself makes an excellent storage box - it easily hold the parts for this set, 10404 (Ocean's Bottom) and 10704 (Creative box from 2017) - around 2350 total parts with plenty of space left for more.

This is an excellent set, and good value for money, (a little more per piece than 10404 (Ocean's Bottom) - but including the plastic box which is good for storage.) The models are fun, with excellent play value, and plenty of addition parts and inspiration.

author: Master_Wu
title: I LOVE it!
review:
If you want a cheap way to get parts, this is the thing for you! It comes with so many parts. With this many parts, you can build anything. It also includes instructions to help you build some of the things you see on the cover. It also has links to a website where there are instructions to build other things if you want to. It includes some classic minifigures as well. This set is packaged in a big red brick which is nice for storing the set in. 

I recommend this set for anyone who is interested in building things, or Lego in general!
